items.title: Wrong HTML Generated for Simple Lists
items.body:
Not sure if I'm overlooking something here, but after creating the most simple `test` project and only modifying the generated `index.md` file to read ``` # Welcome to MkDocs - Item 1 - Item 2 - Item 3 - Item 4 1. First Item 2. Second Item 3. Third Item So what? ``` outputs as HTML ```

Welcome to MkDocs

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  • Item 3

  • Item 4

  • First Item

  • Second Item
  • Third Item

So what?

``` Note the extra paragraph around "Item 4" and the continuation of the unordered list instead of ending it and creating an ordered one, with the "First Item" again being on a separate paragraph. After inserting a separating paragraph between the two lists, like ``` # Welcome to MkDocs - Item 1 - Item 2 - Item 3 - Item 4 Intermediate paragraph. 1. First Item 2. Second Item 3. Third Item So what? ``` the output is correct: ```

Welcome to MkDocs

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  • Item 3
  • Item 4

Intermediate paragraph.

  1. First Item
  2. Second Item
  3. Third Item

So what?

``` Thanks for helping!

items.title: dev_addr 0.0.0.0
items.body:
We use mkdocs in a Docker container for development. Therefore we need `mkdocs serve` to bind to `0.0.0.0`/`::`.

https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/pull/2022 removed this option and is therefore breaking our workflow, and the workflow of many others I suppose.

May I suggest to revert the blocking of `0.0.0.0` and `::` and issue a warning instead of exiting? Or requiring an extra flag like `--never-turn-this-on-in-production` or `--this-is-dangerous` or something alike?

Here are some reasons why we prefer the Docker based dev-environment:

- Our engineers work on various operating systems and technologies. Most don't know Python. So, instead of explaining them how to set up a `venv` and how to run `pip install`, we just have to explain them how to `docker-compose up dev` and get going. (And an occasional `docker-compose build dev`.)
- That's something even our non-engineers understand, who – from time to time – contribute to our docs as well.
- We've had problems before with people not on the same python version, pip version, etc. This is all gone now since we switched to a Docker-based dev environment.

Of course, we can just start an nginx (or whatever proxy) that forwards the traffic to `::1:port`. Or patch-out the change. Or use docker-compose to assign a static IP to the container and bind to that. But that would all be silly workarounds, wouldn't they?

items.title: Sorting the left-side menu
items.body:
I have a simple setup with `docs` containing three files:

```
  index.md
  todo.md
  abc.md
```

They appear on the left menu as:

```
  <header of index.md>
  <header of abc.md>
  <header of todo.md>
```

It seems the order of files is `index.md` first, other files alphabetically by filename.

I do not what the level-one headers to apper on the upper menu yet, just trying to sort the order of files  in left menu.

I can use `nav` in `mkdocs.yaml` that seems to work on both to sort the upper horzontal menu and the leftside menu (is this correct? that seems what documentation suggests).

Mu question is if there is a way to sort the file order on the left menu in specific? 

My ideas: 
 - other static generators may use mardown file _front matter_ for that, is anything similar available in mkdocs?
  - rename source files as `01_filename.md`,`02_filename.md`, etc?
  - some tricky use of `nav` attribute that would take care of left menu sorting, but disable the upper horizontal menu

Many thanks for considering my usecase.

items.title: Change to prevent `0.0.0.0` makes containerized usage painful
items.body: The change in 1.1.1 to prevent the usage of `0.0.0.0` makes using MkDocs in a container painful. We have a local development environment used by our developers which spins up a documentation repository that they can live-edit, with MkDocs hosted inside a Docker container. This is now significantly more difficult.

items.title: Favicon.ico not picked up when using mkdocs serve
items.body:
I set up a minimal project following [the documentation](https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/styling-your-docs/#using-the-theme-custom_dir) to overwrite the favicon.

The favicon is overwritten successfully after running `mkdocs build`, but it is not (both not in the tab and in a bookmark) when viewing the site via `mkdocs serve`. I tested this using Firefox.

items.title: Website generated by mkdocs build not correct (Path issue?)
items.body:
My setting (using Windows 10):
```
PS C:\Users\User\Documents\music\tmp> python --version
Python 3.8.2
PS C:\Users\User\Documents\music\tmp> mkdocs --version
mkdocs, version 1.1 from c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python38-32\lib\site-packages\mkdocs (Python 3.8)
```

I have a simple `mkdocs.yml` file:

```
site_name: MkLorum
nav:
    - Home: 'index.md'
    - About: 'about.md'
```

with the corresponding `md` files.

Running `mkdocs serve` I can view the content of `about.md` at `http://127.0.0.1:8000/about/`.

However, after sucessfully  running `mkdocs build`, `file:///C:/Users/User/Documents/music/tmp/site/about/` (this is where clicking at "About" from the main page takes me) doesn't show any website. Instead it shows a view in which you can navigate the directory structure of the filesystem.

items.body:
It seems like the 'note' text block in [file layout](https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/writing-your-docs/#file-layout) should be formatted like its counterpart in [MultiMarkdown Style Meta-Data](https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/writing-your-docs/#multimarkdown-style-meta-data).

The Markdown for each looks the same, so not sure what's up, just wanted to bring it to your attention.

items.title: Use python static typing info
items.body: If your python project uses things such as [mypy](http://mypy-lang.org/) or [pydantic](https://pydantic-docs.helpmanual.io/), or basically any [python types](https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html), IMHO mkdocs should render those in the docs. If possible, with links to the classes, at least if defined in this same project.

items.title: "There is no disk in the drive" error
items.body:
FYI: I got this error after installing the latest version of mkdocs (1.1) and running the dev server:

    > mkdocs serve

The issue doesn't seem [python related](https://bugs.python.org/issue22739).

The new install included:

    - mkdocs=1.1
    - mkdocs-material=5.1
    - mkdocs-material-extensions=1.0b2

Workaround: downgraded to version mkdocs < 1.1 and mkdocs-material < 5.

No errors.




No error.

items.title: Better deployment integration with Github
items.body:
Hi Team! So i have been using this product for more than a year now, and i absolutely love it! This has been the most manageable solution for a decent static website for me as of now.  

Every aspect of this product is good, but I was wondering if the integration with gh-pages could be made a little more automated.  

Like if I have a website deployed on gh-pages, and somebody wants to edit a small typo in one of the pages. The process to fix that typo would go something like this:  

1. They will make a PR changing the markdown file in the `docs` .  
2. I will be reviewing their PR and manually merging it  
3. i will be then pulling the changes on my local system  
4. then i would be doing `mkdocs gh-deploy` which would generate new web page and deploy it

is there a way i could  skip steps 3 and 4 and make the website automatically generate  as soon as a new change is made in the `docs` folder ?

items.body: Is it "make docs" or "M K docs"?

items.title: Include documents from relative paths on the built site
items.body:
Hi, thanks for the great tool, we are very happy with it at SoundCloud.

One of our codebases is a multi-module project, each owned by different teams and with different sub-structures. One android app is built from the combination of all sources, and in a similar fashion, we provide an internal documentation website using mkdocs for the entire development team.

One of the limitations we see so far, though, is including markdown files that aren't under the `docs` directory under our root. Some teams prefer to have `README` files or other pieces of documentation side-by-side with the code under each module, take a look at the example directory structure (starting from the root dir):

```
- mkdocs.yml
- docs/
  - onboarding/
    - file1.md
    - file2.md
  - releasing/
  - testing/
- libs/
  - networking/
    - README.md
    - docs/
      - apiclient.md
      - caching.md
  - analytics/
- ...
```

So far, all of the files under the `docs` directory in the root are included in the built website, but we would also like to have another section for the documents under each module. In the example above, we would like a "networking" section with the `md` files under its `docs` directory (namely `apiclient.md` and `caching.md`).

We explored using the [nav configuration setting](https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/configuration/#nav) but since it only considers paths under `docs_dir`, we cannot express a navigation like:
```
nav:
    - 'Networking': '../libs/networking/README.md'
```
I see a printed log line with
```
WARNING -  A relative path to '../libs/networking/README.md' is included in the 'nav' configuration, which is not found in the documentation files
```


We could have separate built websites, and link between them, but ideally we would rather have a single deployment with all aggregated documentation.

Is this possible? Or maybe I am doing something wrong?

items.title: Plugins and strict mode
items.body:
Is there a recommended way for plugins to plug themselves on `mkdocs` logging system? I'm particularly interested in making the build or serve commands fail when I log a warning.

Looking at the code, I see that I can simply do

```python
import logging

from mkdocs.utils import warning_filter

log = logging.getLogger(__name__)
log.addFilter(warning_filter)
```

...and then use `log.warning("message")` normally.

Is this the recommended method or is there a better way?

Also, it seems that warnings only will be counted:

```python
if record.levelno == logging.WARNING
```

Shouldn't errors and critical errors be counted as well, to make the build/serve commands fail?

Happy to send the following patch if yes :smile:!

```python
if record.levelno >= logging.WARNING
```

items.title: Install of mkdocs fails with nltk 3.5
items.body:
Hi,

First of all, thank you for mkdocs. We're using this in our company and are very happy to have it.

I noticed that the installation of mkdocs started failing for us yesterday. After some investigation I found out that the [nltk](https://www.nltk.org/install.html) lib had a version bump (3.5) yesterday and that's were it goes wrong.

I was able to use the previous nltk version (3.4.5) by adding it directly to our ci file
```
pages:
  image: python:3.7-alpine
  stage: 🥾 Bootstrap
  script:
    - pip install nltk==3.4.5
    - pip install mkdocs
    - pip install mkdocs-material
    - mkdocs build
```
This solves the issue for us.

I am not really used to python and its ecosystem, so perhaps I am overseeing an actual "fix".
But if this is a really issue, I guess the `3.5` nltk version should be _blacklisted_ from the install?

items.title: ReadTheDocs theme: Page does not expand to whole viewport
items.body: Hello, I am seeing some page layout inconsistency in MkDocs while using *readthedocs* theme. Why there is grey area on the right of the page while serving the page via localhost? I do not see such while uploaded to GitHub and served via readthedocs.io There the page stretches over the whole viewport. This issue was not there in the earlier version 1.0.4 of MkDocs. Replacing the *readthedocs* theme folder from earlier version resolves the issue. Would you please look into issue with current version? Thank you.

items.title: MkDocs overrides folders that it shouldn't
items.body:
I want to combine my API documentation and the wiki made with MkDocs in the same `docs` folder.
I want to have the built index.html in the docs folder (as a welcome page of sorts) while keeping the wiki related stuff inside a wiki folder and all API documentation in a api folder.

So you can imagine the structure as follows:
```
|- docs
    |
    |- index.html
    |- api
    |   |
    |   |- <My API docs>
    |
    |- wiki
        |
        |- <My Wiki>
```

I have setup MkDocs with the following folder structure. Note that this is **not** in the docs folder, but instead in a separate folder called wiki.
```
|- wiki
    |
    |- mkdocs.yml
    |- docs
    |   |
    |   |- index.md
    |   |
    |   |- wiki
    |       |
    |       |- <My Wiki>
    |
    |- theme
        |
        |- <Custom Theme stuff>
```

So in total the entire folder structure of my project is like this:
```
|- project
    |
    |- docs
    |   |
    |   |- index.html
    |   |
    |   |- wiki
    |   |   |
    |   |   |- <My Wiki>
    |   |
    |   |- api
    |       |
    |       |- <My API docs>
    |
    |- wiki
        |
        |- mkdocs.yml
        |
        |- docs
            |
            |- index.md
            |- wiki
            |   |
            |   |- <My Wiki>
            |
            |- theme
                |
                |- <Custom Theme stuff>
```

----
## The issue
When building the pages using `mkdocs build` does MkDocs delete the entire api folder, which contains all api documentation I have.
This is frustrating as I then have to rebuild those separately, which costs me time.

Is there any setting to ignore specific folders in the build-directory, so that won't be removed/altered?
If not, could this be added as a feature, as this is quite annoying?

I really like to use MkDocs (Thanks for this software guys), but to be honest, the support for it is "limited" to say the least.

While IRC is a good platform does not everyone like to use it. And the same also goes for the Google Forum about MkDocs: While it may be a place for asking questions and receiving answers does not everyone like to actually be part of it (especially if it makes you watch every forum post there by default D:<)

Other options like GitHub issues or StackOverflow questions are again not the best option as it could be slow to receive an answer to an urgent question (or you don't get an answer at all \*glares over to StackOverflow*)

So I was asking if there's any other platform (i.e. a (Community) Discord server) for receiving support for various questions regarding MkDocs...

items.title: ENHANCEMENT REQ: Make sections clickable links that default to index or first child
items.body:
It would be really nice to not have to create a custom theme or extend the templates just to get a section to act as a clickable link which defaults to an index.html at the root of that section or the first child link or page as defined in the nav config. Take the following example:

Given a nav config of:
```
Nav:
  - Home: index.html
  - User Guide: 
    - ‘Writing your docs’: ‘/user-guide/writing-your-docs.md’ 
    - ‘Styling your docs’: ‘/user-guide/styling-your-docs.md’
  - About:
    - ‘License’: ‘/about/license.md’
    - ‘Release notes’: ‘/about/release-notes.md’
```
And a directory structure of:
```
Project
├── mkdocs.yml
├── .gitignore
├── docs
     ├── index.md
     ├── user-guide
         ├── index.md
         ├── writing-your-docs.md
         ├── styling-your-docs.md
     ├── About
         ├── index.md
         ├── license.md
         ├── release-notes.md
```
The root/home page of the site is obviously going to be at `docs/index.html` and we know that most web servers are going to return an `index.html` for any the root of any directory, so why should any customization at all be required for making a section a clickable link that navigates to the index.html at their root?

To take it a step further, in the absence of an `index.html` at the root of those directories, it would be far more intuitive if the sections still remained clickable links and just defaulted to the first child that were a page or link.

items.title: Why is mkdocs trying to create a folder named after an old folder?
items.body:
Hello,

Just started with mkdocs, having a mildly annoying time so far.

I renamed my old docs source from "docs" to "olddocs", with the intention of creating a new folder called "docs" with the mkdocs command.

Problem is, mkdocs is now trying to use "olddocs" as the folder name. Why? I never instructed it to do this, how could it ever know that this folder should be used?

```shell
mkdocs -v new .
INFO    -  Writing config file: .\mkdocs.yml
INFO    -  Writing initial olddocs: .\olddocs\index.md
```

This seems to be contrary to what the command is meant to do, based on the source:
https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/blob/master/mkdocs/commands/new.py

Any ideas why this is happening and how to prevent it?

items.title: Lists behavior as in GitHub?
items.body:
Is there a way to make a list behavior the same way as in GitHub?

Now, MkDocs doesn't make a list if there is no leading blank line before list items. For example: 


```
This is a list:
* Item1
* Item2
```

..wouldn't be converted to a list.

And this code would be converted to a list as there is a blank line before list items:

```
This is a list:

* Item1
* Item2
```

items.title: https://mkdocs.org causes security error while https://www.mkdocs.org doesn't
items.body:
When connecting to https://mkdocs.org, does the anti-virus (in my case Kaspersky Internet Security) report the URL as "not secure"?
When you, however, connect to https://www.mkdocs.org does this warning not appear.

This also is made clear, when posting both links into a Chat (e.g. Discord): https://mkdocs.org doesn't load/display any meta/og information, while https://www.mkdocs.org does.

I suggest fixing this issue, as I assume people will prefer using mkdocs.org over www.mkdocs.org

items.title: Curly brace and hash is causing: Missing end of comment tag
items.body:
When I have a code block in markdown:

```html
<div th:unless="${#bean.method()}">
```

And try to build the mkdocs with `mkdocs build` I get an error:
```
jinja2.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError: Missing end of comment tag
```

This is because of the `{#` sequence in the code block. I don't want to escape the characters because someone might get the example from the markdown, not the built docs, and such value would not work.

**Environment**
Python: `3.8`
MkDocs: `1.0.4` and `1.1`

**Full trace:**
```
ERROR   -  Error reading page 'some-file.md': Missing end of comment tag 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mkdocs", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(cli())
  File ".../python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 829, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File ".../python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 782, in main

items.title: Incorrect wording
items.body:
https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/blob/c9032bd6bfde09ead2f4f879e85590d7cd6e68a6/mkdocs/config/config_options.py#L357-L359

I discovered this error when trying to set `docs_dir: .`, which produced:
```
$ mkdocs serve
INFO    -  Building documentation...
ERROR   -  Config value: 'docs_dir'. Error: The 'docs_dir' should not be the parent
directory of the config file. Use a child directory instead so that the config file is
a sibling of the config file.
```

The first confusing thing that caught my eye was "the config file is a sibling of the config file."

items.title: Section in menu  with page assigned

The documentation states clearly that a parent menu button cannot have a page assigned but if one would like to what would be the best way to achieve this? The reason is that we use MkDocs to generate ontology documentation files with parent and subclass relationships. When a subclass is present in the submenu the parent class cannot be assigned a document. A hack-work-around would be to modify the generated html code as it does contain the possibility but the href is empty. ```
  • Process
      • ``` Is there a better solution to achieve this? For example by adding the md file in the yaml documentation directly after the parent directory? > Note that a section cannot have a page assigned to it. Sections are only containers for child pages and sub-sections. You may nest sections as deeply as you like. However, be careful that you don't make it too difficult for your users to navigate through the site navigation by over-complicating the nesting. While sections may mirror your directory structure, they do not have to.

items.title: mkdocs/structure/toc.py, line 59, in _parse_toc_token TypeError: string indices must be integers
items.body:
It seems to be because of this change: https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/pull/1970/files#diff-568fb30129902a6310b43ce5e37dfbb6R10 (from v1.0.4 to v1.1.0).

I'm using `page.toc = get_toc(getattr(md, "toc", ""))` in my code.
Supposed quick fix on my side (not tested yet):

```diff
-page.toc = get_toc(getattr(md, "toc", ""))
+page.toc = get_toc(getattr(md, "toc_tokens", []))
```

I'm not sure if this should be considered breaking change or not (is `structure.toc.get_toc` considered public API?). Maybe it was already deprecated some time ago and I missed the warning?

I'll update my code asap so feel free to close, I just opened for the sake of reporting 🙂

items.title: No-op code snippet in nav.py? (Page objects for files not in nav seem to be discarded)
items.body:
While debugging an issue with two mkdocs plugins that aren't working well together, I stumbled across [L120-123](https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/blob/master/mkdocs/structure/nav.py#L120-L123) in `mkdocs/structure/nav.py`), which read as follows.
```python
# Any documentation files not found in the nav should still have an associated page.
# However, these page objects are only accessable from File instances as `file.page`.
for file in missing_from_config:
    Page(None, file, config)
```
The last line doesn't seem to have any effect: the `Page` object is constructed and then immediately discarded.

Should it instead be assigned to something (e.g. to `file.page` as seems to be implied by the comment)?
```python
for file in missing_from_config:
    file.page = Page(None, file, config)
```
I hope I'm not misinterpreting what's happening here, I hope a core developer can clarify the intention of this part of the code. Many thanks!

items.title: Nested dot folders copied upon build

milestone.description: Features to be included in the 1.1 release.

items.body:
Sometimes it's necessary to include files in a theme which MkDocs should conditionally include in the templates, but not copy to the `site` directory when the documentation is built. As discussed in #1980, MkDocs will ignore files that start with a `.`, but this only applies to top-level directories. It would be great if MkDocs could exclude nested dot directories from the build.

A concrete example: the next version of the Material theme will bundle the FontAwesome files as SVGs for inlining during build time, but MkDocs copies all of them to the `site` directory. The folder structure is:

```
assets/images/icons/fontawesome/...
```

The current workaround is to add a `*.html` to the files bundles with the theme, resulting in a `*.svg.html` extension for each of the 1.500 icons. While this works, it's semantically incorrect.

If MkDocs would ignore nested dot directories, we could just use:

```
assets/images/icons/.fontawesome/...
```

As pointed out by @waylan, the code in question is here:

https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/blob/2fca717794c0c2e581b8ba17149bc292edeb83e4/mkdocs/structure/files.py#L67-L69

I'm not proficient in Python, but since this looks like a glob implementation, I would guess that `**/.*` would solve the problem

items.title: Theme-option to specify theme-specific assets to not be copied
items.body: For the latest Material theme, I'm switching to an SVG-based approach for FontAwesome which will reduce the payload by a huge margin, i.e. the SVGs are directly included from the Jinja templates, and thus must be distributed with the theme: ```jinja {% include "assets/images/icons/fontawesome/" ~ social.icon ~ ".svg" %} ``` The problem is, that on `build`, MkDocs will copy over all SVG files that are part of the theme, thus the build takes quite long and there're a lot of unnecessary file that should not be part of the build. I've skimmed through the docs but didn't find an option to say: please don't include files under this directory. Ideally, as a theme author, I would like to specify which theme files are only necessary during build time and need not be distributed.

items.title: Load categories README.md
items.body:
FIrst of all, thank you for the awesome program.

I was wondering if there was a way that the navigation panel would load the README of the categories.

Imagine the following directory tree:

```
└── docs
    ├── about.md
    └── life_automation
        ├── taskwarrior.md
        ├── grocy.md
        └── README.md
```

I'd like to have the following `nav` bar:

```yaml
nav:
  - About: 'about.md'
  - Life Automation: 
      - Grocy: life_automation/grocy.md
      - Taskwarrior: life_automation/taskwarrior.md
```

So when anyone clicks over the `Life Automation` menu, it get's unfolded and the `life_automation/README.md` get's loaded. This is the default behavior for GitBooks, (see an [example](https://wiki.nikitavoloboev.xyz/meta).

With the current behavior, I see the following options:

```yaml
nav:
  - Life Automation: 
      - Introduction: life_automation/README.md
      - Grocy: life_automation/grocy.md
```

Which looks good in the nav bar, but the *next* and *previous* lower buttons are not descriptive.

Or using `Life Automation` in place of `Introduction`, which looks good in the *next* and *previous* buttons, but looks bad in the nav bar.

How do you usually tackle this cases?

I've searched in the issues but I haven't found a solution, sorry if I missed it.

items.title: Refer to same file several times in contents
items.body:
Hello!
I am building a project which should have two structure trees. So in the contents there will be two branches which refer to the same files with different subcaptions and different level of nesting.

For example, I have a source file `auth.md` and I want it to appear two times, nested under `Basic -> Authentication` subcaptions, and `Alternative -> Auth` subcations. I define pages like this:

```yaml
pages:
- basic:
  - "Authentication": auth.md
- Alternative:
  - "Auth": auth.md
```

It all seems to work, but no matter which link I click in the contents:

![](https://i.imgur.com/tsF0sNu.png)

After the page loads, I have always the "Alternative" subcaption active in contents:

![](https://i.imgur.com/NZbZ5CE.png)

Is there a way to point mkdocs which link was clicked if there are several links pointing to one file in the contents?

# Resource Accounting Policy

## Wall-Clock Core-Hours WCH

The wall-clock core-hours (WCH) are the basic metric of computer utilization time.
1 wall-clock core-hour is defined as 1 processor core allocated for 1 hour of wall-clock time. Allocating a full node (16 cores Anselm,  24 cores Salomon)
for 1 hour amounts to 16 wall-clock core-hours (Anselm) or 24 wall-clock core-hours (Salomon).

## Normalized Core-Hours NCH

The resources subject to accounting are the normalized core-hours (NCH).
The normalized core-hours are obtained from WCH by applying a normalization factor:
```

items.title: How to add a watched directory
items.body:
The docs says:

> The serve event is only called when the serve command is used during development. It is passed the Server instance which can be modified before it is activated. For example, additional files or directories could be added to the list of "watched" files for auto-reloading.

How can I add files or directories?

I tried this:

```python
    def on_serve(self, server, config, **kwargs):
        for element in self.config["watch"]:
            server.watch(element)
        return server
```

With this in my `mkdocs.yml`:

```yaml
plugins:
  - search
  - mkdocstrings:
      watch:
        - src/mkdocstrings
```

It detects the changes, but since I gave no function to `server.watch(dir, func)`, the site is not rebuilt.

I checked the source code of `mkdocs`, and I see that you are using a local function that we cannot reuse ourselves without rewriting it:

https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/blob/262c2b70f3b1a450d685530610af3f28e12f9c9f/mkdocs/commands/serve.py#L120-L137

and

https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/blob/262c2b70f3b1a450d685530610af3f28e12f9c9f/mkdocs/commands/serve.py#L69

What would be the best way to add a directory with this same `builder` functionality? Should I simply copy paste it?
